channel.title: Electra - Powerful, fast, experimental [NEW BASE]
channel.description:
I'd appreciate a comment, no matter what it is. Responses, positive and negative, are welcome. I actually listen to input, and if you think I should change something, then I'll look into it. I don't see much sense in making a download thread for something that isn't near completion, this is more a project thread than anything else at the moment.
NOTE: I don't really pay attention to moparscape as much as I do... some other site... but I'll try and make an effort to respond to both.
[URL=https://github.com/SuprahFry/Electra][IMG]http://i.imgur.com/o9b7G.png[/img][/URL]
Repository: [URL=https://github.com/SuprahFry/Electra]GitHub[/URL] Download snapshot (v0.1 11/12/12 11:28pm EST, cache included): [URL=http://uppit.com/xgrp4hhadqze/Electra_0.1.rar]UppIT[/URL], [URL=http://www.sendspace.com/file/nt4t7q]SendSpace[/URL]
[IMG]http://i.imgur.com/lvO9b.png[/img]
[B][SIZE=5]Introduction[/SIZE][/B]
Electra is a server that is created to be intuitive, well designed, and fast. It's currently under development and many things have yet to be implemented. Electra isn't designed to be a new base that will work with other clients. I'm not going to limit myself to strictly the work that Jagex did 7 years ago, and neither should you. I plan on actually maintaining and constantly improving the server, so it's not just a one-off base release like literally every other base out there has been so far.
[B][SIZE=4]Features[/SIZE][/B]
[ul][li]Math parser and evaluator, used in the compiler for converting expressions into bytecode for array lengths but can also be used in your projects as well. You can translate infix (the notation humans use) to postfix notation. From postfix notation you can evaluate the expression.[/li] [li]Efficient networking via Java's NIO API.[/li] [li]An improved and more usable event/handler system.[/li] [li]An extremely efficient and 'coder'-friendly network event (packet) system.[/li] [li]Support for reconnecting instead of just forcing the old player to disconnect and reload the same player as a different instance. Only the client that opened the original connection can reconnect to a session.[/li] [li]Simple and non-redundant naming conventions for variable and method names. [I]You may dislike this, but it's too late to change now. It'll grow on you![/I][/li] [li]The login block is encrypted using RSA. This means that every session is secure as long as the private key is unknown. Change the private/public key set if you're going to use this publicly.[/li] [li]Cache file and cache archive reading.[/li] [li]JAGGRAB and OnDemand file server for cache updating.[/li][/ul]
[IMG]http://i.imgur.com/FAbyU.gif[/img]
[B][SIZE=4]Planned[/SIZE][/B]
[ul][li]More than just walking around ;)[/li] [li]Player saving and loading[/li] [li]Login server with support for any amount of worlds. (Way down the line, though)[/li] [li]More complete player updating (actually updating other players)[/li] [li]Segmented player updating (improving our standards, etc.)[/li] [li]Better event compilation with support for arrays and expressions.[/li] [li]Super awesome interface system so you don't have to hardcode IDs.[/li] [li]Porting over my server-sided clipped walking/following code from a C# server I wrote.[/li] [li]All the general RuneScape content-related stuff like skills and stuff.[/li] [li]In-game map editor (this is probably going to take a long time and a lot of work)[/li] [li]Checksum checking on login (easy, just keep putting it off for no reason)[/li] [li]Figuring out why the client gets confused when I send too much data to it over a short amount of time. This really just applies to JAGGRAB and OnDemand freaking out when all the data is being sent/read all at the same time.[/li] [li]Something better than a file associating eventhandlers to events.[/li] [li]Benchmarks and core improvements based on if the server can handle 2k players without cycle desyncing. I'm sure I can make it work with just one thread, to keep the design simple.[/li][/ul]
[B][SIZE=3]Dependencies[/SIZE][/B]
[ul][li][URL=http://code.google.com/p/snakeyaml/]SnakeYAML[/URL] - YAML parser and emitter for configuration files[/li] [li][URL=http://commons.apache.org/bcel/]Apache Commons BCEL[/URL] - Bytecode Engineering Library for event 'compiler'[/li] [li][URL=http://commons.apache.org/compress/]Apache Commons Compress[/URL] - For BZip2 compression/decompression in the cache[/li][/ul]
[B][SIZE=3]Compatibility notes[/SIZE][/B] I've taken it upon myself to simplify and modify the client. The modifications I've made are to make the design of the server simpler. I've simplified the protocol (no random data types), removed unused anti-cheat packets (which are useless now anyway), etc.; and the enabling of RSA, JAGGRAB, and OnDemand makes this client incompatible with any other servers and this server incompatible with other clients.
[SIZE=3][B]Credits[/B] ([URL=https://github.com/SuprahFry/Electra#credits]full list[/URL])[/SIZE]
[ul][li]Graham/Apollo - I took some ideas out, built on them, and, I feel, definitely improved them.[/li] [li]blakeman8192/RuneSource - I used this as a crutch to wrap my head around NIO way back when[/li] [li]Nikki - For her "Enabling RSA" thread that I used as a reference. I also included/used her key generator.[/li][/ul]
If this project thread becomes dead due to lack of responses, the server will not die. I'm invested into this project regardless of whether or not people find it useful or not. Even with me saying that, I'm still nervous and unsure if people are going to like it. There's definitely something to learn if you're willing to read some code!
Here we go. Thanks pals.

item.title: Electra - Powerful, fast, experimental [NEW BASE]
item.dc:creator: @ExtremeX-Scape Ryley
item.description:
@ExtremeX-Scape wrote:

Your BitStore, is… interesting. I added you on Skype.

Read full topic

item.title: Electra - Powerful, fast, experimental [NEW BASE]
item.dc:creator: @Supah_Flyizzle Supah Flyizzle
item.description:
@Supah_Flyizzle wrote:

AtomicInt_:

Supah Flyizzle, you may encounter problems with your localPlayers List as a List does not contain order, player updating requires a maintained order when entering, iterating, and removing from the list. A LinkedHashSet would best suite you here it has fairly good performance and maintains that required order.

hence “temporary,” there’s no way i’m letting it stay that way.

[quote]add(E e)
Appends the specified element to the end of this list.[/quote]

it doesn’t just reorder elements when i iterate through them, it does it in the way they are in the list.

Or perhaps a custom one, or even a BitSet possibly.

github.com

sarchive/Electra/blob/master/src/net/electra/io/BitStore.java

package net.electra.io;

// essentially just for lots and lots of single bit flags.
public class BitStore
{
	private int count = 0;
	private byte[] store;
	
	public BitStore(int size)
	{
		store = new byte[(size + 7) >> 3];
	}
	
	public void clear()
	{
		store = new byte[(store.length + 7) >> 3];
		count = 0;
	}
	
	public boolean get(int index)
This file has been truncated. show original

as for sinisoul, i know the design is kind of… fragmented. i’m kind of at this weird point where i’m just trying to do something and keep it consistent, i don’t really have anyone that is willing to discuss things with me (i imagine that graham, blake, or even possibly super would if i were to message them asking for advice). not to mention incorporating nio into this is like a first shot for me so, admittedly i have limited understanding of that. for everything else it’s just me trying to eliminate global state as much as possible by trying to put things in places i think they belong.

i imagine using netty would help clean up the network code clutter and, by extension, clear up some root design flaws. i understand designs, i truly do. it’s just a matter of stevie-wondering it until i finally figure out something. i don’t know what i’m going to do as far as changing network even compiling (what it does now).

also you guys feel free to discuss what you’re talking about here since it’s actually kind of relevant in a way. zomgtehfly is my skype if you feel like talking.

Read full topic

item.title: Electra - Powerful, fast, experimental [NEW BASE]
item.dc:creator: @ExtremeX-Scape Ryley
item.description:
@ExtremeX-Scape wrote:

Perhaps I should have been more specific; A LinkedHashSet has a predictable iteration order, in that it maintains a doubly-linked list running through all of its entries, the elements are iterated in the order that they were added, and the insertion order is not affected if the entry is re-entered into the Set.

Read full topic

item.description:
@Metho_D wrote:

[quote=“AtomicInt_, post:32, topic:467775”]Supah Flyizzle, you may encounter problems with your localPlayers List as a List does not contain order, player updating requires a maintained order when entering, iterating, and removing from the list. A LinkedHashSet would best suite you here it has fairly good performance and maintains that required order.

Or perhaps a custom one, or even a BitSet possibly.[/quote]

What do you mean? Lists are ordered by definition.

item.title: Electra - Powerful, fast, experimental [NEW BASE]
item.dc:creator: @Supah_Flyizzle Supah Flyizzle
item.description:
@Supah_Flyizzle wrote:

Uncalled:

Want to share that player updating code? I’d love to check it out!

if i had written it already, i wouldn’t have written the temporary code. essentially it deals with sending multiple update packets, segmenting the data so that we don’t overflow the client’s buffer, keeping track of what appearances the client has cached (it caches appearances of players, if you didn’t know) for people that might leave and re-enter your range of visibility, facing the right way when first appearing, etc.

Read full topic
